data.title: Data Set 3.8
data.text:
TheÂ DBpedia data setÂ uses aÂ large multi-domain ontology which hasÂ been derived from Wikipedia. TheÂ English version ofÂ the DBpedia 3.8 data setÂ describes 3.77 million "things"Â with 400 million "facts".

InÂ addition, weÂ provide localized versions ofÂ DBpedia inÂ 111 languages. AllÂ these versions together describe 20.8 million things, outÂ ofÂ which 10.5 million overlap (are interlinked) with concepts from theÂ English DBpedia. TheÂ full DBpedia data setÂ features labels andÂ abstracts forÂ 10.3 million unique things inÂ up toÂ 111 different languages; 8.0 million links toÂ images andÂ 24.4 million HTML links toÂ external webÂ pages; 27.2 million data links into external RDFÂ data sets, 55.8 million links toÂ Wikipedia categories, andÂ 8.2 million YAGO categories. TheÂ dataset consists ofÂ 1.89 billion pieces ofÂ information (RDF triples) outÂ ofÂ which 400 million were extracted from theÂ English edition ofÂ Wikipedia, 1.46 billion were extracted from other language editions, andÂ about 27 million areÂ data links toÂ external RDFÂ data sets.

Â

1Â Background

WikipediaÂ hasÂ grown into oneÂ ofÂ the central knowledge sources ofÂ mankind andÂ isÂ maintained byÂ thousands ofÂ contributors. Wikipedia articles consist mostly ofÂ free text, butÂ also contain different types ofÂ structured information, such asÂ infobox templates,Â categorisation information, images, geo-coordinates, andÂ links toÂ external WebÂ pages. ForÂ instance, theÂ figure below shows theÂ source code andÂ the visualisation ofÂ an infobox template containing structured information about theÂ town ofÂ Innsbruck.

Â

TheÂ DBpedia project extracts various kinds ofÂ structured information from Wikipedia editions inÂ 111 languages andÂ combines this information into aÂ huge, cross-domain knowledge base.

DBpedia uses theÂ Resource Description Framework (RDF) asÂ a flexible data model forÂ representing extracted information andÂ for publishing itÂ on theÂ Web. WeÂ use theÂ SPARQLÂ query language toÂ query this data. Please refer toÂ theÂ Developers Guide toÂ Semantic WebÂ ToolkitsÂ toÂ find aÂ development toolkit inÂ your preferred programming language toÂ process DBpedia data.

2Â Content ofÂ the DBpedia Data Set

TheÂ English version ofÂ the DBpedia knowledge base currently describes 3.77 million things, outÂ ofÂ which 2.35 million areÂ classified inÂ a consistentÂ Ontology, including 764,000 persons, 573,000 places (including 387,000 populated places), 333,000 creative works (including 112,000 music albums, 72,000 films andÂ 18,000 video games), 192,000 organizations (including 45,000 companies andÂ 42,000 educational institutions), 202,000 species andÂ 5,500 diseases.

InÂ addition, weÂ provide localized versions ofÂ DBpedia inÂ 111 languages. AllÂ these versions together describe 20.8 million things, outÂ ofÂ which 10.5 million overlap with theÂ concepts from theÂ English Dbpedia. TheÂ full DBpedia data setÂ features labels andÂ abstracts forÂ 10.3 million unique things inÂ 111 different languages; 8.0 million links toÂ images andÂ 24.4 million links toÂ external webÂ pages; 27.2 million external links into other RDFÂ datasets, 55.8 million links toÂ Wikipedia categories, andÂ 8.2 million YAGO categories. TheÂ dataset consists ofÂ 1.89 billion pieces ofÂ information (RDF triples) outÂ ofÂ which 400 million were extracted from theÂ English edition ofÂ Wikipedia, 1.46 billion were extracted from other language editions, andÂ about 30 million areÂ links toÂ external datasets. Detailed statistics about theÂ DBpedia datasets inÂ 22 popular languages areÂ provided atÂ Dataset Statistics.

TheÂ table below contains links toÂ some example "things" from theÂ data set:

Â

Class Examples City Cambridge,Â Berlin,Â Manchester Country Spain,Â Iceland,Â South Korea Politician George W. Bush,Â Nicolas Sarkozy,Â Angela Merkel Musician AC/DC,Diana Ross,Â RÃ¶yksopp Music album Led Zeppelin III,Â Like aÂ Virgin,Â Thriller Director Woody Allen,Â Oliver Stone,Â Takashi Miike Film Pulp Fiction,Â Hysterical Blindness,Â Breakfast atÂ Tiffany's Book The Lord ofÂ the Rings,Â The Adventures ofÂ Tom Sawyer, theÂ Bible Computer Game Tetris,Â World ofÂ Warcraft,Â Sam & MaxÂ hit theÂ Road Technical Standard HTML,Â RDF,Â URI

YouÂ can also useÂ Richard Cyganiak's PHPÂ script toÂ view random thingsÂ from theÂ DBpedia data set.

Find theÂ properties used inÂ the different DBpedia data sets here?.

3Â Denoting orÂ Naming "things"

Each thing inÂ the DBpedia data setÂ isÂ denotedÂ byÂ a de-referenceableÂ IRI- orÂ URI-based reference ofÂ the formhttp://dbpedia.org/resource/Name, whereÂ NameÂ isÂ derivedÂ from theÂ URL ofÂ the source Wikipedia article, which hasÂ the formÂ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Name. Thus, each DBpedia entity isÂ tied directly toÂ a Wikipedia article. Every DBpedia entity name resolves toÂ a description-oriented WebÂ document (or WebÂ resource).

Until DBpedia release 3.6, weÂ only used article names from theÂ English Wikipedia, butÂ since DBpedia release 3.7, weÂ also provideÂ localized datasetsÂ that contain IRIs likeÂ http://xx.dbpedia.org/resource/Name, whereÂ xxÂ isÂ a Wikipedia language code andÂ NameÂ isÂ taken from theÂ source URL,Â http://xx.wikipedia.org/wiki/Name.

Starting with DBpedia release 3.8, weÂ use IRIs forÂ most DBpedia entity names. IRIs areÂ more readable andÂ generally preferable toÂ URIs, butÂ for backwards compatibility, weÂ still useÂ URIs forÂ DBpedia resources extracted from theÂ English Wikipedia andÂ IRIs forÂ all other languages. Triples inÂ Turtle files useÂ IRIs forÂ allÂ languages, even forÂ English.

There areÂ several details onÂ theÂ encoding ofÂ URIsÂ that should always beÂ taken into account.

4Â Describing "things"

Each DBpedia entity isÂ described byÂ various properties. Below, weÂ give anÂ overview about theÂ most important types ofÂ properties.

4.1Â Basic Information

Every DBpedia resource isÂ described byÂ a label, aÂ short andÂ long English abstract, aÂ link toÂ the corresponding Wikipedia page, andÂ aÂ link toÂ an image depicting theÂ thing (if available).

IfÂ a thing exists inÂ multiple language versions ofÂ Wikipedia, then short andÂ long abstracts within these languages andÂ links toÂ the different language Wikipedia pages areÂ added toÂ the description. TheÂ DBpedia data setÂ contains theÂ following numbers ofÂ abstracts perÂ language (July 2012):

Â

Language Number ofÂ Abstracts English 3,770,000 German 1,244,000 French 1,197,000 Dutch 993,000 Italian 882,000 Spanish 879,000 Polish 848,000 Japanese 781,000 Portuguese 699,000 Swedish 457,000 Chinese 445,000

4.2Â Classifications

DBpedia provides three different classification schemata forÂ things.

Â

Wikipedia CategoriesÂ areÂ represented using theÂ SKOS vocabularyÂ andÂ DCMI terms.

TheÂ YAGO ClassificationÂ isÂ derived from theÂ Wikipedia category system using WordNet. Please refer toÂ Yago: AÂ Core ofÂ Semantic Knowledge â Unifying WordNet andÂ Wikipedia (PDF) forÂ more details.

WordNet Synset LinksÂ were generated byÂ manually relating Wikipedia infobox templates andÂ WordNet synsets, andÂ adding aÂ corresponding link toÂ each thing that uses aÂ specific template. InÂ theory, this classification should beÂ more precise then theÂ Wikipedia category system.

Using these classifications within SPARQL queries allows youÂ toÂ select things ofÂ a certain type.

4.2.1Â Wikipedia Categories

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20%20. } ==NBA TeamsÂ (Does notÂ work with Internet Explorer)

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20%20. }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Car manufacturers

4.2.2Â YAGO Classes

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20rdf:type%20. ?subject%20rdfs:label%20?label. ?subject%20rdfs:comment%20?abstract. FILTER%20(lang(?label)%20=%20"en"%20&&%20lang(?abstract)%20=%20"en") }%20LIMIT%2020 ==European Capitals

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20rdf:type%20. ?subject%20rdfs:label%20?label. ?subject%20rdfs:comment%20?abstract. FILTER%20(lang(?label)%20=%20"en"%20&&%20lang(?abstract)%20=%20"en") }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Birds ofÂ the United States

4.2.3Â Wordnet

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20dbpedia2:wordnet_type%20. ?subject%20rdfs:label%20?label. ?subject%20rdfs:comment%20?abstract. FILTER%20(lang(?label)%20=%20"en"%20&&%20lang(?abstract)%20=%20"en") }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Software

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20dbpedia2:wordnet_type%20. ?subject%20rdfs:label%20?label. ?subject%20rdfs:comment%20?abstract. FILTER%20(lang(?label)%20=%20"en"%20&&%20lang(?abstract)%20=%20"en") }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Airlines

4.3Â Infobox Data

Wikipedia infoboxes contain very specific information about things andÂ are thus aÂ very valuable source ofÂ structured information that canÂ beÂ used toÂ ask expressive queries against Wikipedia. TheÂ DBpedia project currently extracts three different datasets from theÂ Wikipedia infoboxes.

Â

TheÂ Infobox DatasetÂ isÂ created using ourÂ initial, nowÂ three year oldÂ infobox parsing approach. This extractor extracts allÂ properties from allÂ infoboxes andÂ templates within allÂ Wikipedia articles. Extracted information isÂ represented using properties inÂ theÂ http://dbpedia.org/property/Â namespace. TheÂ names ofÂ the these properties directly reflect theÂ name ofÂ the Wikipedia infobox property. Property names areÂ not cleaned orÂ merged. Property types areÂ not part ofÂ a subsumption hierarchy andÂ there isÂ no consistent ontology forÂ the infobox dataset. Currently, there areÂ approximately 8000 different property types. TheÂ infobox extractor performs only aÂ minimal amount ofÂ property value clean-up, e.g., byÂ converting aÂ value like "June 2009" toÂ the XMLÂ Schema format "2009-06". YouÂ should therefore useÂ the infobox dataset only ifÂ your application requires complete coverage ofÂ all Wikipeda properties andÂ you areÂ prepared toÂ accept relatively noisy data.

TheÂ Infobox Ontology. With theÂ DBpedia 3.2 release, weÂ introduced aÂ new infobox extraction method which isÂ based onÂ hand-generated mappings ofÂ Wikipedia infoboxes/templates toÂ a newly createdÂ DBpedia ontology. TheÂ mappings adjust weaknesses inÂ the Wikipedia infobox system, like using different infoboxes forÂ the same type ofÂ thing (class) orÂ using different property names forÂ the same property. Therefore, theÂ instance data within theÂ infobox ontology isÂ much cleaner andÂ better structured than theÂ Infobox Dataset, butÂ currently doesn't cover allÂ infobox types andÂ infobox properties within Wikipedia. Starting with DBpedia release 3.5, weÂ provide three different Infobox Ontology data sets:

TheÂ Ontology Infobox TypesÂ dataset contains theÂ rdf:types ofÂ the instances which have been extracted from theÂ infoboxes.

TheÂ Ontology Infobox PropertiesÂ dataset contains theÂ actual data values that have been extracted from infoboxes. TheÂ data values areÂ represented using ontology properties (e.g., 'volume') that mayÂ beÂ applied toÂ different things (e.g., theÂ volume ofÂ a lake andÂ the volume ofÂ a planet). This restricts theÂ number ofÂ different properties toÂ a minimum, butÂ has theÂ drawback that itÂ is notÂ possible toÂ automatically infer theÂ class ofÂ an entity based onÂ a property. ForÂ instance, anÂ application that discovers anÂ entity described using theÂ volume property cannot infer that that theÂ entity isÂ a lake andÂ then forÂ example useÂ aÂ map toÂ visualize theÂ entity. Properties areÂ represented using properties following theÂ http://dbpedia.org/ontology/{propertyname} naming schema. AllÂ values areÂ normalized toÂ their respective SIÂ unit.

TheÂ Ontology Infobox Properties (Specific)Â dataset contains properties which have been specialized forÂ aÂ specific class using aÂ specific unit. e.g. theÂ property height isÂ specialized onÂ the class Person using theÂ unit centimetres instead ofÂ metres. Specialized properties follow theÂ http://dbpedia.org/ontology/{Class}/{property} naming schema (e.g.http://dbpedia.org/ontology/Person/height). TheÂ properties have aÂ single class asÂ rdfs:domain andÂ rdfs:range andÂ can therefore beÂ used forÂ classification reasoning. This makes itÂ easier toÂ express queries against theÂ data, e.g., finding allÂ lakes whose volume isÂ in aÂ certain range. Typically, theÂ range ofÂ the properties areÂ not using SIÂ units, butÂ aÂ unit which isÂ more appropriate inÂ the specific domain.

AllÂ three data sets areÂ available forÂ downloadÂ asÂ well asÂ being available forÂ queries viaÂ the DBpedia SPARQL endpoint.

TheÂ infobox data enables sophisticated, fine-grained queries over theÂ data set. Some example queries areÂ shown below:

4.3.1Â Querying theÂ Infobox Dataset

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20?subject%20?label%20?released%...{ ?subject%20rdf:type%20. ?subject%20dbpedia2:starring%20. ?subject%20rdfs:comment%20?abstract. ?subject%20rdfs:label%20?label. FILTER(lang(?abstract)%20=%20"en"%20&&%20lang(?label)%20=%20"en"). ?subject%20%20?released. FILTER(xsd:date(?released)%20<%20"2000-01-01"^^xsd:date). }%20ORDER%20BY%20?released LIMIT%2020 ==Abstracts ofÂ movies starring TomÂ Cruise, released before 1999

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20DISTINCT%20?subject%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20?employees%20 %20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20?homepage%20 %20%20WHERE%20 %20%20%20%20{ %20%20%20%20%20%20?subject%20%20rdf:type%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20. %20%20%20%20%20%20?subject%20%20dbpedia2:numEmployees%20%20?employees %20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20FILTER%20%20(%20xsd:integer(?employees)%20>=%2050000%20)%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20. %20%20%20%20%20%20?subject%20%20foaf:homepage%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20?homepage%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20. %20%20%20%20}%20 %20%20ORDER%20BY%20%20DESC(xsd:integer(?employees)) %20%20LIMIT%20%2020 ==The official websites ofÂ companies with more than 50000 employees

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20?subject%20?population%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20rdf:type%20. ?subject%20%20?population. FILTER%20(xsd:integer(?population)%20>%202000000) } ORDER%20BY%20DESC(xsd:integer(?population)) LIMIT%2020 ==Cities with more than 2 million habitants

4.3.2Â Querying theÂ Infobox Ontology

List allÂ episodes ofÂ the HBOÂ television series TheÂ Sopranos ordered byÂ their air-date:

Â

SELECT * WHERE { ?e <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/series> <http://dbpedia.org/resource/The_Sopranos> . ?e <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/releaseDate> ?date . ?e <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/episodeNumber> ?number . ?e <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/seasonNumber> ?season } ORDER BY DESC(?date)

Â

http://dbpedia.org/sparql?default-graph-uri=http://dbpedia.org&query=sel...Â where { ?e%20%20%20. ?e%20%20?date%20. ?e%20%20?number%20. } order%20by%20desc(?date)&format=text/html&debug=on ==SPARQL Result

Software developed byÂ an organisation founded inÂ California:

Â

SELECT * WHERE { ?company a <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/Organisation> . ?company <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/foundationPlace> <http://dbpedia.org/resource/California> . ?product <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/developer> ?company . ?product a <http://dbpedia.org/ontology/Software> }

Â

http://dbpedia.org/sparql?default-graph-uri=http://dbpedia.org&query=sel...Â where {%20?company%20a%20%20. ?company%20%20%20. ?product%20%20?company%20%20. ?product%20%20a%20%20. } &format=text/html&debug=on ==SPARQL Result

4.4Â External Links

TheÂ DBpedia data setÂ contains HTML links toÂ external webÂ pages asÂ well asÂ RDF links into external data sources.

There areÂ two types ofÂ links toÂ HTML pages: dbpedia:reference links point toÂ several webÂ pages about aÂ thing. InÂ addition, some things also have foaf:homepage links that point toÂ web pages that canÂ beÂ considered theÂ "official homepage" ofÂ a thing.

RDFÂ links areÂ represented using theÂ owl:sameAs property. Please refer toÂ InterlinkingÂ forÂ more information about RDFÂ links andÂ the interlinked data sets.

4.4.1Â FOAF Homepage

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?s%20foaf:homepage%20?h. ?s%20rdf:type%20. }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Official websites ofÂ Universities

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?city%20foaf:homepage%20?homepage%20. ?country%20rdf:type%20%20. ?country%20%20?city%20. }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Official websites ofÂ Capitals

4.4.2Â owl:sameAs Links

Geographical (toÂ GeoNames.org,Eurostat data, andÂ the RDFÂ version ofÂ theÂ CIA Factbook):

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20owl:sameAs%20?link. ?subject%20rdf:type%20 }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Countries

Authors / Books (toÂ quotationsbook.comÂ andÂ Project Gutenberg RDF. Links toÂ theÂ RDF Book MashupÂ will follow soon ):

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20owl:sameAs%20?link. ?subject%20rdf:type%20 }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Authors

Computer Scientist publicationsDBLP:

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20owl:sameAs%20?link. ?subject%20rdf:type%20 }%20LIMIT%2020 ==DBLP

U.S. Census Statistical DataÂ rdfabout.com, RDFÂ version byÂ Joshua Tauber:

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=SELECT%20*%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20owl:sameAs%20?link. ?subject%20%20%20%20. }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Links forÂ States ofÂ the U.S.A.

4.5Â Geo-Coordinates

TheÂ DBpedia data setÂ contains geo-coordinates forÂ 986,000 geographic locations. Geo-coordinates areÂ expressed using theÂ W3C Basic GeoÂ Vocabulary.

Besides simple listings ofÂ geo-coordinates (e.g.,Â http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=PREFIX%20geo:%20Â SELECT%20?subject%20?lat%20?long%20WHERE%20{ ?subject%20%20. ?subject%20geo:lat%20?lat. ?subject%20geo:long%20?long. }%20LIMIT%2020 ==German soccer stadiumsÂ ), theÂ new geo-coordinates allow sophisticated queries, like "show meÂ all things next toÂ the":

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=PREFIX%20geo:%20Â SELECT%20?subject%20?label%20?lat%20?long%20WHERE%20{ %20geo:lat%20?eiffelLat. %20geo:long%20?eiffelLong. ?subject%20geo:lat%20?lat. ?subject%20geo:long%20?long. ?subject%20rdfs:label%20?label. FILTER(?lat%20-%20?eiffelLat%20<=%200.05%20&&%20?eiffelLat%20-%20?lat%20<=%200.05%20&& ?long%20-%20?eiffelLong%20<=%200.05%20&&%20?eiffelLong%20-%20?long%20<=%200.05%20&& lang(?label)%20=%20"en" ). }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Eiffel Tower

http://dbpedia.org/snorql/?query=PREFIX%20geo:%20Â SELECT%20?subject%20?label%20?lat%20?long%20WHERE%20{ %20geo:lat%20?brandenburgLat. %20geo:long%20?brandenburgLong. ?subject%20geo:lat%20?lat. ?subject%20geo:long%20?long. ?subject%20rdfs:label%20?label. FILTER(?lat%20-%20?brandenburgLat%20<=%200.05%20&&%20?brandenburgLat%20-%20?lat%20<=%200.05%20&& ?long%20-%20?brandenburgLong%20<=%200.05%20&&%20?brandenburgLong%20-%20?long%20<=%200.05%20&& lang(?label)%20=%20"en" ). }%20LIMIT%2020 ==Brandenburg Gate

5Â Provenance Meta-Data

InÂ addition toÂ the triples provided byÂ the N-Triples datasets, theÂ N-Quads datasets include aÂ provenance URIÂ toÂ each statement. TheÂ provenance URIÂ denotes theÂ origin ofÂ the extracted triple inÂ Wikipedia.

TheÂ provenance URIÂ isÂ composed ofÂ the URIÂ ofÂ the article from Wikipedia where theÂ statement hasÂ been extracted andÂ aÂ number ofÂ parameters denoting theÂ exact source line.

TheÂ following parameters areÂ set:

absolute-line: TheÂ (absolute) line inÂ the Wikipedia article source. TheÂ first line ofÂ a source hasÂ the line number 1.

relative-line: TheÂ line inÂ the Wikipedia article source inÂ respect ofÂ the current section.

section: TheÂ section inside theÂ article

Example:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW_7_Series#section=E23&relative-line=1&ab...

TheÂ source ofÂ the given statement canÂ beÂ found inÂ the 23th line. ItÂ is located inÂ the first line ofÂ the section "E23".

6Â Localized Datasets

TheÂ localized datasets contain theÂ complete DBpedia data from non-English Wikipedias. Until DBpedia release 3.6, weÂ extracted data from non-English Wikipedia pages only ifÂ there exists anÂ equivalent English page, asÂ we wanted toÂ have aÂ single URIÂ toÂ identify aÂ resource across allÂ 97 languages. However, since there areÂ many pages inÂ the non-English Wikipedia editions that doÂ not have anÂ equivalent English page (especially small towns inÂ different countries, e.g. theÂ Austrian village Endach, orÂ legal andÂ administrative terms that areÂ just relevant forÂ aÂ single country) relying onÂ English URIs only hadÂ the negative effect that DBpedia didÂ not contain data forÂ these entities andÂ many DBpedia users have complained about this shortcoming.

Since theÂ DBpedia 3.7 release, weÂ provide localized DBpedia editions forÂ download that contain data from allÂ Wikipedia pages inÂ a specific language. InÂ DBpedia 3.7, these localized editions covered theÂ following 15 languages: ca, de, el, es, fr, ga, hr, hu, it, nl, pl, pt, ru, sl, tr. Starting with DBpedia 3.8, weÂ provide localized DBpedia editions forÂ all languages.

TheÂ IRIs identifying entities inÂ these internationalized datasets areÂ constructed directly from theÂ non-English title andÂ aÂ language-specific URIÂ namespaces (e.g.Â http://ja.dbpedia.org/resource/ãã«ãªã³), soÂ there areÂ now many different URIs inÂ DBpedia that refer toÂ Berlin.

WeÂ also extract theÂ inter-language links from theÂ different Wikipedia editions. Thus, whenever bijective inter-language links between aÂ non-English Wikipedia page andÂ its English equivalent exists, theÂ resulting owl:sameAs link canÂ beÂ used toÂ relate theÂ localized DBpedia URIÂ toÂ the equivalent inÂ the main (English) DBpedia edition. TheÂ localized DBpedia editions areÂ provided forÂ download onÂ theÂ DBpedia download page.

Note that notÂ all localized editions provide public SPARQL endpoints, norÂ doÂ all localized URIs dereference. This might change inÂ the future, asÂ more local DBpedia chapters areÂ set upÂ in different countries asÂ part ofÂ theÂ DBpedia internationalization effort.

AllÂ DBpedia IRIs/URIs inÂ the canonicalized datasets useÂ the generic namespaceÂ http://dbpedia.org/. ForÂ backwards compatibility, theÂ N-Triples files (.nt, .nq) useÂ URIs, e.g.Â http://dbpedia.org/resource/BoÃÂ¶tes. TheÂ Turtle (.ttl) files useÂ IRIs, e.g.Â http://dbpedia.org/resource/BoÃ¶tes.

TheÂ localized datasets useÂ DBpedia IRIs (not URIs) andÂ language-specific namespaces, e.g.http://el.dbpedia.org/resource/ÎÎµÏÎ¿Î»Î¯Î½Î¿.

6.1Â Directory structure andÂ file names

ForÂ the DBpedia 3.7 release, weÂ created twoÂ separate folders onÂ thedownload server:Â /3.7/Â forÂ the datasets using 'English' URIs,Â /3.7-i18n/Â forÂ the datasets using 'local' URIs. Since theÂ 3.8 release, weÂ abandoned this high-level distinction andÂ instead offer different dataset files inÂ the download folder forÂ each language, where theÂ files with 'local' IRIs areÂ named after their dataset, while theÂ files with 'English' URIs/IRIs appendÂ _en_urisÂ toÂ the dataset name. Examples:

/3.7/de/labels_de.nt.bz2Â ->Â /3.8/de/labels_en_uris_de.nt.bz2Â (Canonicalized dataset, 'English' URIs)

/3.7-i18n/de/labels_de.nt.bz2Â ->Â /3.8/de/labels_de.nt.bz2Â (Internationalized dataset, 'local' IRIs)

6.2Â Data SetÂ Statistics

Â

Dataset StatisticsÂ provides detailed statistics about theÂ DBpedia datasets inÂ 22 languages.

Cross-Language StatisticsÂ provides statistics about theÂ cross-language overlap ofÂ instances andÂ property values between these lanuages.

7Â iPopulator

iPopulatorÂ isÂ a system that automatically populates infoboxes ofÂ Wikipedia articles byÂ extracting attribute values from theÂ article's text. TheÂ dataset contains newÂ extracted information andÂ complements DBpedia's attribute values.

8Â Datasets forÂ Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Each andÂ every dataset from DBpedia isÂ potentially useful forÂ several tasks related toÂ Natural Language Processing (NLP) andÂ Computational Linguistics. WeÂ have described inÂ Datasets/NLPÂ aÂ few examples ofÂ how toÂ use these datasets. Moreover, weÂ describe aÂ number ofÂ extended datasets that were generated during theÂ creation ofÂ DBpedia Spotlight andÂ other NLP-related projects.

9Â License

DBpedia isÂ derived fromWikipediaÂ andÂ isÂ distributed under theÂ same licensing terms asÂ Wikipedia itself. AsÂ Wikipedia hasÂ moved toÂ dual-licensing, weÂ also dual-license DBpedia starting with release 3.4.

DBpedia data from version 3.4 onÂ is licensed under theÂ terms ofÂ theÂ Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0license andÂ theÂ GNU Free Documentation License. AllÂ DBpedia releases upÂ to andÂ including release 3.3 areÂ licensed under theÂ terms ofÂ theÂ GNU Free Documentation LicenseÂ only.

AttributionÂ inÂ this case meansÂ keep DBpedia URIs visible andÂ active through atÂ least oneÂ (preferably all) ofÂ @href, <link />, orÂ "Link:".Â IfÂ live links areÂ impossible (e.g., when printed onÂ paper), aÂ textual blurb-based attribution isÂ acceptable.

This material isÂ Open Knowledge.
